H0.text: They will stop producing energy because wind and water are examples of renewable energy sources.

H1.text: They were formed millions of years ago, so wind and water are examples of renewable energy sources.

H2.text: They are always available to produce energy, which is why wind and water are examples of renewable energy sources.

H3.text: They take millions of years to start producing energy, which is why wind and water are examples of renewable energy sources.

A4.text: Variable renewable energy sources are those that have a fluctuating nature, such as wind power and solar power.

A5.text: Renewable energy is energy made from renewable natural resources that are replenished on a human timescale.

A6.text: Wind power goes through predictable variation by season, but is intermittent on a daily basis.

A7.text: Hydroelectricity can be increased or decreased in seconds or minutes in response to varying electricity demand.

A8.text: In many places, wind and solar generation are complementary on a daily and a seasonal scale: there is more wind during the night and in winter when solar energy production is low.

A9.text: Renewable energy is sustainable in its production; the available supply will not be diminished for the foreseeable future - millions or billions of years.

A10.text: Wind energy could also be produced even if the climate changes in line with current predictions, as it relies solely on wind.
